abstract.p: A method of optimizing the arrangement of hammers and fenders on a Scrap Metal Shredder is presented. It offers a means of reducing dynamic unbalance force. A dynamic balance model is established for analyzing rotor unbalance force. The model is verified by software simulation. Ant Colony Optimization Algorithms (ACOA) are then introduced to arrange hammers and fenders. Meanwhile, ACOA has been improved by introducing a multi-dimensional matrix and random number q0 and separating the first loop from other loops. A rational arrangement of hammers and fenders is obtained. The studies show that using ACOA to arrange hammers and fenders can significantly reduce the dynamic unbalance force. For unbalance force of the rotor, the maximum reduction can be up to 92.6% compared with the original arrangement before optimization.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Rotor is one of the most important parts of the Scrap Metal Shredder. The lopsided parts on the rotor will cause vibration and noise when it is running in high speed, and can even shorten the life of the shredder. There are many reasons, such as the quality of manufacturing, balance correction, installation and foundation, leading the Scrap Metal Shredder to be unsteady and have serious vibrations. However, the wear of hammers and uneven distribution of the mass are the two main reasons that cause unsteady and serious vibration (Aboussouan and Russo, 1999). Hammers distributed in different planes will generate eccentric force when the rotor is running, which will cause vibration and will speed up the wear of hammers if the unbalance forces cannot be balanced out by each other. Uneven mass has a significant impact on the dynamic balance of the hammer shredder, so the arrangement of hammers and fenders and the design of dynamic balance are critical to the rotor on the Scrap Metal Shredder (Austin, 2004; Sander and Schubert, 2004).

Nowadays, the basic way to arrange hammers and fenders usually has the following steps. First, weigh all hammers and fenders and make sure the weight of them is equal to or close to each other, weight difference within 0.1 kg. Then, arrange hammers and fenders and make sure the eccentric forces are balanced out by each other as much as possible. Finally, verify whether the arrangement meets the requirements of the dynamic balance or not (Wijk and Herder, 2009), and if not, re-do the above work. After several experiments, this method can get a satisfactory result. However, it needs to verify whether the result meet the requirements of dynamic balance design or not aftereach arrangement. This process needs a large amount of computation and is time consuming.

In this study, a combinatorial optimization algorithm is employed to deal with the above large computation problem. First, weigh all hammers and fenders, then use optimization algorithms to obtain a reasonable arrangement of hammers and fenders. At last, verify the arrangement through ADMAS (MSC Software, USA) simulation. There are many combinatorial optimizationalgorithms being used to solve complicated problems inengineering applications, such as genetic algorithms, simulated annealing, particle swarm optimization andAnt Colony Optimization Algorithms (ACOA) (Bertsimas and Tsitsiklis, 1992; Dorigo et al., 1991)Among the above methods, ACOA is characterized by intelligent search, global optimization, strong robustness and distributed computation, which provides a new way to settle complicated problems. So ACOA is selected as the optimization algorithm to optimize the arrangement of hammers and fenders.

In order to avoid the shortcomings of the algorithm, such as slow convergence, being time consuming, and easily trapped in local minimum, ACOA has made some improvements, as follows: (1) Store the pheromones by a multi-dimensional matrix to avoid the interference of different pheromones; (2) Separate the first loop and make it different from other loops to expand the range of options by applying different mechanisms;(3) Introduce random number q0, Change the value of it according to convergence of the algorithmtoavoid premature and continuing divergence. Calculation results and simulation results show that the dynamic unbalance force reduce significantly after optimization.

sec.title: 2. Dynamic balance design for rotor on scrap metal shredder
2.1. Theory of dynamic balance design
sec.p: For dynamic unbalanced rotor, the process of “balancing” is the removal or addition of weight to any two selected planes on the rotor. In order to reduce the massof the whole machine, the lighter the weight of matching blocks, the better. When a well-balanced shaft and a well-balanced rotor are assembled, the necessary assembly tolerances can permit radial displacement, which will generate an unbalanced condition. So the rotor cannot be completely well-balanced; the ultimate aim is to reduce the unbalance at an acceptable level.

sec.title: 2.2. Rotor parameters
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the 3D model of the rotor on PFY2026 Scrap Metal Shredder, which consists of one spindle, 39 hammers, 12 hammer plates (two side hammer plates), six hammer shafts, 21 common fenders and six side fenders (placed in both sides of the rotor). The rotor is large scale, high speed (595 r/min) and leptosomatic. The working radius of hammers is φ 2000 mm and the working length of the rotor is 2790 mm. The average mass of hammers is 131.7 kg are set in the form of six rows by 11 columns. The average mass of common fenders is 221 kg. The average mass of side fenders is 255 kg. Hammers and fenders are cross-arranged, one row of hammers and one row of fenders (used to protect hammer plates). Based on experience, dividing hammers and fenders into three groups (heavy, middle and light) by weight. Some rules should be observed when arranging hammers and fenders:
The mass on the same radial plane should be equal to or close to each other.
The mass on axisymmetric surfaces is equal to or close to each other and the maximum deviation is less than 20 kg.
Hammers and fenders are cross-arranged in the form of heavy–light.

sec.title: 2.3. Dynamic balance model of rotor
sec.p:
According to the dynamic balance principles, each of the hammers and fenders can be substituted by two concentrated masses mi ' and mi '; these masses are located on two arbitrarily chosen correction planes. The resultant eccentric force on each plane can be calculated when the rotor runs at a fixed speed. Figure 2 shows the simplified model of the rotor. Planes from 1 to 11 represent 11 rows of hammer and fender plates. Plane I and plane II represent correction planes. Figure 2.
Simplified model of the rotor145 × 59 mm (96 × 96 DPI).

Hammers and fenders are swinging-up when the rotor is running, which will swing back and forth within a very small angle range when hit by scrap metal. Suppose that this impact can be ignored, the geometric centerline and the centroids of hammers and fenders can be thought to coincide. The turning radius of each hammer or fender is equal to the distance between geometric centerline and centroids of the corresponding hammer or fender. In this study, the turning radius of all hammers is supposed to be the same and the turning radius of all fenders is also equal to each other. The mass of all hammers and fenders is not the same, so the mass-radius product of hammers and fenders is different.

sec.title: 3. Overview of ant colony optimization algorithms
sec.p: Inspired by the action of ant colonies foraging, Italian researcher M. Dorigo initially proposed ACOA in 1991. ACOA is used at first to settle the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP). In this section, we will takeTSP as an example to illustrate the process of ACOA. Let V = {1, 2, …, n} be a set of cities, D={ (i,j)|i,j∈V} be the edge set, d(i, j) = d(j, i) be a cost measure associated with edge (i, j) ∈ D. TSP is a problem of finding a minimal cost closed tour that visits each city once (Bianchi and Gambardella, 2002; Dorigo and Gambardella, 1997). The objective function is given by equation (10). Suppose that m ants do n kinds of move from the moment t to the next moment t + 1, this process is named as an iteration. The algorithm completes one cycle when the iteration is carried out n times. The state transition rule used by an ant system is given by equation (11), which gives the probability with which ant k in city i chooses to move to the city j. (11) where

ρ is the local pheromone decay parameter, 0 < ρ < 1. The pheromone would not be reserved completely, it volatilizes by a constant decrease ρ in each iteration.
Δτij k, a certain quantity of pheromones left by ant k who chooses (i, j) at moment t, the amount of which is given by equation (13). (13) where
Q represents the total pheromones released by ants in one cycle, which is constant.
Lk is the total length covered by ant k in one cycle.

allowk(i) is the set of remaining cities that can be visited by ant k positioned on city i. In fact, allowk = {n - tabuk}.

First, put m ants in n cities randomly, when Nc = 1 (the first cycle), τij = 0. Ants choose the path primarily based on ηij, store the path that ant k has covered into taboo table tabuk, at the same time, ant k has covered into taboo table k chooses the next city from allowk and continues to move forward until it completes all cities. After a full run, each ant leaves a certain quantity of pheromones Δτij kon its course, pheromones would not be reserved completely, some of them will volatilize by a constant decrease ρ. When Nc ≥ 2, ants choose cities primarily on the basis of Pij. According to the abovementioned process, ants will find the shortest path with cycles Nc increasing.

sec.title: 4. Arrangement of hammers and fenders using ant colony optimization algorithms
sec.p: There are 66 positions on the rotor of PFY2026 Scrap Metal Shredder, 39 for hammers, 21 for common fenders, and six for side fenders. Let Fi = miriω2 be multiplied by the coefficient Li '/L and Li ''/L respectively, then projected to X axis and Y axis, we will obtain four 66 × 66 matrixes (AX, AY, BX and BY). Because each matrix has the same structure, here we take matrix AX for an example.

As shown in Figure 5, adding the virtual starting point a0 in the first column of AX, formed a 66 × 67 matrix. Each row corresponds to an object i(i = 1, 2, …, 66), each column corresponds to a position j (j = 0, 1, …, 66). Node aij represents the centrifugal force of the object i at position j . Once aij has been defined, it means object i and position j have been used, which cannot be used any longer and will be stored in Tabu. The optimization objective is to make the sum of the elected nodes (eccentric force) minimum. Figure 5.
Centrifugal force distribution in the form of nodes 71 × 35 mm (96 × 96 DPI).

Ant k starts at a0 and selects a suitable object i for each location j step by step. The state transition rule is given by equation (14), which gives the probability with which ant k choose the next node aij. (14) where
allowk(aij)={aij|aij∉ tabuk} is the feasible region, ant k chooses the next node aij only in this region.
tabuk is a set including all the nodes that have been chosen by ant k.

τij(t) is given by equation (11), but Δτij contains two parts: global increase Δτij kand the elitist ants increase Δ(τij k)' (elitist ants, which traversed the shortest path RNc, deposit a large quantity of pheromone, with a view to increase the probability of other ants of exploring the most promising solution) (see Dreo et al., 2006). The former is given by equation (15) and the latter is given by equation (16). (15) (16) where
Q represents the total pheromones released by ants in one cycle, which is constant.
Fk is the resultant force corresponding to arrangement Rk in one cycle.
RNc is one arrangement of hammers and fenders, the resultant FNc corresponding to RNc is minimum in Nc cycles.
In order to avoid volatile pheromones completely, the value of pheromones should be limited by τmin and τmax (Gutjahr, 1999).

In order to avoid the algorithm being premature to a local minimum, ACOA introduces another transition rule depending on a parameter q0 ∈ [0, 1], which is given by equation (17): (17) where q is a random variable uniformly distributed in [0, 1].

This transition rule favors transitions toward nodes connected by small resultant and with a large amount of pheromone. Every time an ant chooses the next node aij, it samples a random number q, if q < q0, the ant will make the best choice according to equation (17), otherwise the node aij is selected at random according to equation (14). In fact, for q < q0, the algorithm exploits the information that has been collected by the system and it cannot choose a non-explored path.

sec.title: 4.1. Improvements of ant colony optimization algorithms

list-item.p: In order to avoid the interference of different pheromones (hammers, common fenders and side fenders), we introduce a 66 × 67 matrix with 66-dimension in this algorithm. In the nth step, Store τuv in row u and column v of the nth dimension, τuv represents the pheromone from node u to node v. Calculate the probability pn(n+1) k from the nth step to the (n + 1)th step by applying pheromone in the (n + 1)th dimension.

Separate the first cycle from other cycles. In the first cycle, pheromone τij=0, ants will depend on ηij completely when choosing the next node, which will reduce the probability of finding the minimum. So separate the first cycle and make it different from other cycles.

Change the value of q0 according to convergence of the algorithm. q0 owns the capability of helping ants to find the optimum, the path will be changed when the algorithm is in the local optimal solution. Ants will find the better path within a certain cycle because they are not limited to the current pheromones. However, if q0 is too large and the local optimal solution is too small, ants cannot find the optimum along the shortest paths that have been found, which will lead to the convergence time being too long. Figure 6 shows the effect of results by q0. So it is necessary to change the value of q0 step by step according to the convergence of the algorithm. After calculating, the results showed that ants can find the optimal value effectively in accordance with pheromone when the range of q0 is (0.7, 0.9).

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: This study primarily introduced a method of optimizing the arrangement of hammers and fenders on a Scrap Metal Shredder. Applying improved ACOA to arrange the hammers and fenders not only obtained a rational arrangement but also reduced the design time of the Scrap Metal Shredder.

The study takes the rotor on a PFY2026 Scrap Metal Shredder as a research object, and establishes the mathematical optimization model based on a dynamic balance principle. It is a discrete global optimization problem and the best way to solve this problem is to find out a fast and efficient computer optimization algorithm. ACOA has been introduced to optimize the arrangement of hammers and fenders in this study.

After optimization, the mass on the same radial plane is well-balanced and the unbalanced force on the rotor issignificantly reduced. Before optimization, the unbalance force is 10238.0 N. After optimization, the unbalance force reduced to 752.2 N – the reduction is up to 92.6%. Meanwhile a reasonable arrangement of hammers and fenders has been obtained, which is a good guide for designing a Scrap Metal Shredder.
